render.tex: \title{Direction Cosines and Ratios} \\ %text Direction cosines $(l,m,n)$ and ratios $(a,b,c)$ of a line %

reason.tex: %text A line in three dimensional geometry may be expressed as, % \begin{align} \dfrac{x-x_1}{a}=\dfrac{y-y_1}{b}=\dfrac{z-z_1}{c} \end{align} \\ %text For such a line, the{\bf direction ratios} are $a$, $b$ and $c$. The{\bf direction cosines} $(l,m,n)$ on the other hand can be established as shown. % \begin{align} l &= \dfrac{a}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}} \\ m &= \dfrac{b}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}} \\ n &= \dfrac{c}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}} \end{align} \\ %text Sometimes a line may be perpendicular to one or more of the axes, in which case the expressions above change. For example, % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Equation} & \text{Type of line} & (l, m, n) \\ \hline x=2,y=4 &\text{parallel to $z$ axis} & (1,1,0) \\ & \text{$\perp$ to $x$ and $y$ axes} &\\ \hline \dfrac{x-1}{3}=\dfrac{y+3}{2}, z=9 & \text{$\perp$ to $z$ axis} & \small{\left(\frac{3}{\sqrt{13}},\frac{2}{\sqrt{13}},0\right)} \\ \hline \dfrac{x-9}{2}=\dfrac{z+1}{1}, y=4 & \text{$\perp$ to $y$ axis} & \small{\left(\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}},0,\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}\right)}\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align}
